results.title: A Country Practice
results.brief_description: A Country Practice was a beloved Australian television drama series that was one of the longest-running dramas of its kind at the time.

constellations_other.name: Black Power through film and TV
constellations_other.description: The Black Power movement of the late 1960s and early 70s was “the most exciting and dynamic era in modern Indigenous history” according to Aboriginal activist Professor Gary Foley, who gained widespread attention for protests during the time and later leveraged film and TV to fight for Indigenous rights.

constellations_other.name: Jill Bilcock
constellations_other.description: An editor’s work often goes unnoticed, but they’re scene-stitching not only brings the director’s vision to life but sometimes steals the show. One of Australia’s greatest editors, Jill Bilcock, has shaped some of the country’s most memorable screen stories.

results.description: A Country Practice was an Australian television drama series. At its inception, one of the longest-running of its kind, produced by James Davern of JNP Productions, who had wrote the pilot episode and entered a script contest for the network in 1979, coming third and winning a merit award. It ran on the Seven Network for 1,058 episodes from 18 November 1981 to 22 November 1993. It was produced in ATN-7’s production facility at Epping, Sydney. After its lengthy run on the seven network it was picked up by network ten with a mainly new cast from April to November 1994 for 30 episodes, although the ten series was not as successful as its predecessor . The Channel Seven series was also filmed on location in Pitt Town, while, the Channel Ten series was filmed on location in Emerald, Victoria.
description_for_label: A Country Practice was an Australian television drama series. At its inception, one of the longest-running of its kind, produced by James Davern of JNP Productions, who had wrote the pilot episode and entered a script contest for the network in 1979, coming third and winning a merit award. It ran on the Seven Network for 1,058 episodes from 18 November 1981 to 22 November 1993. It was produced in ATN-7’s production facility at Epping, Sydney. After its lengthy run on the seven network it was picked up by network ten with a mainly new cast from April to November 1994 for 30 episodes, although the ten series was not as successful as its predecessor . The Channel Seven series was also filmed on location in Pitt Town, while, the Channel Ten series was filmed on location in Emerald, Victoria.

results.title: Green Fingers: Looking After Lemons
results.brief_description:
‘Green Fingers’ was a series of short instructional films on home gardening tips, produced by the Victorian Department of Agriculture. In this episode, ‘Looking After Lemons’, gardener Rod Cantrill shows ways to look after the popular lemon tree.

The narrator points out various issues that can afflict them including collar rot, leaf yellowing, leaf fall, and pests and diseases, while Cantrill works on lemon trees in a beautiful orchard. The episodes of ‘Green Fingers’ are an early example of popular gardening shows in the tradition of ‘Sow What’, ‘Better Homes and Gardens’, and ‘Gardening Australia’.

results.title: Green Fingers: Indoor Plants
results.brief_description:
‘Green Fingers’ was a series of short instructional films on home gardening tips, produced by the Victorian Department of Agriculture. In this episode, ‘Indoor Plants’, gardener Rod Cantrill demonstrates how to propagate and look after indoor plants.

The film contains wonderful footage of the glasshouses at Burnley Horticultural College, with plants shown including rubber plants, philodendron and rex begonias. The episodes of ‘Green Fingers’ are an early example of popular gardening shows in the tradition of ‘Sow What’, ‘Better Homes and Gardens’, and ‘Gardening Australia’.

results.title: Green Fingers: Pest and Disease Control
results.brief_description:
Please be advised: this is an archival film and contemporary advice should be sought when handling chemicals and poisons.

‘Green Fingers’ was a series of short instructional films on home gardening tips, produced by the Victorian Department of Agriculture. In this episode, ‘Pest and Disease Control’, Rod Cantrill demonstrates how to use agricultural sprays on a rose garden at Burnley Gardens.

Diseases described include black spot, aphids and powdery mildew. The episodes of ‘Green Fingers’ are an early example of popular gardening shows in the tradition of ‘Sow What’, ‘Better Homes and Gardens’, and ‘Gardening Australia’.

results.title: [John Anderson Home Movies: Reel 17]
results.brief_description:
John Robert (Jack) Anderson (1924–1993) was a film distributor, cinema owner and photographer as well as an enthusiastic filmmaker in and around Ballarat in Victoria. Jack developed an interest in film very early at cinema shows and gained his first film experience while serving in WWII, photographing wartime conditions and aircraft involved in the defence of Australia’s north, including the aftermath of the Darwin bombing raid.

It was whilst working in photographic studios that Jack met his future wife, business partner and fellow film enthusiast Marie Bourke. Starting out by hiring films and showing them around regional Victoria, Jack and Marie established cinemas such as the Astor Cinema in Ararat, Bell Post Hill Drive-In in Geelong and the Southern and Northern Drive-Ins and Vegas 70 Cinema in Ballarat. In the 1970s, the Anderson family acquired and restored the Regent Theatre in Ballarat which would then become the first multiplex in regional Victoria.

Along the way, Jack filmed his family and friends activities and outings, horse racing, Ballarat street scenes, motorcycle scrambling and travel scenes on the road – an unusual and wonderful look at life in regional Victoria during the 1940s to the 1960s.

This film presents a glimpse of a somewhat nostalgic version of Australian suburban family life as it was in the 50s and early 60s.

This film was originally made using 16mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:07:00 children playing with sprinkler and toys 1950s
00:02:19:00 leaving hospital with baby
00:03:39:00 a 1950s Christmas scene; children with toys
00:04:59:00 brief shot of Queenscliff with kids riding in Cobb & Co. horse-drawn carriage
00:06:53:00 girl jumping on a trampoline with pier in the background – trampoline park with interesting “trampolines” sign
00:08:59:00 nice shot of toddler waddling towards the camera
00:12:54:00 backyard children’s birthday party
00:17:05:00 young girl using a hula hoop in a paddock
00:18:02:00 toddler gets a home haircut

results.title: Hubby gets a Hobby
results.brief_description:
This short film, ‘Hubby Gets a Hobby’, was directed by Keith Greenwood and presented by KenRa Films (Kenneth Rankine). The black-and-white, silent film pokes fun at the amateur film community (which Rankine was a part of) with a story of a husband taking up amateur cinematography as a hobby, much to his wife’s displeasure. The film’s comedic narrative comes from the husband’s obsessive focus on cameras and film equipment as his wife objects to his new hobby (demonstrating now-outdated gender stereotypes). By the end of the film, he is vindicated by capturing footage of a building fire, which is used in a newsreel, and eventually his wife is seen taking up a camera as well.

The film is notable for its footage of early models of consumer cameras, including 16mm hand-wound Bell and Howell and Kodak cameras. It also includes footage of the Victorian Amateur Cine Society filming a production about Captain Cook outside Cook’s Cottage in Fitzroy Gardens. According to an opening sequence title cards, the film was awarded a prize by the Victorian Amateur Cine Society in 1947.

Kenneth Carruthers Rankine (1890 - 1968) was a keen amateur cinematographer and filmmaker. This collection of his home movies has been donated to ACMI by Kenneth’s granddaughter. The collection represents a wonderful slice of life in Australia; with contents including scenes of everyday life, major family occasions, holidays around Victoria and views of Melbourne.

results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 27]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur filmmaker who was particularly keen on capturing the Australian landscape from the 1960s to the 1990s. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

In this film the ‘Walkabouters’ go to Werribee Gorge State Park in Victoria for one of their walks. On this visit, they see spiders, flowers and fungi, look for rock samples and do some fence making and tree planting.

A particular point of interest is an early Coolabah brand wine cask. Established in 1962, Orlando Coolabah was one of the first commercially successful cask wine brands in Australia and very popular in the 1970s. The wine cask itself was invented and perfected in Australia, initially by Angoves Wines in South Australia.

This film also shows some mushrooms and the practice of ‘mushrooming’ in grassy farm paddocks, equipped with buckets and knives.

Originally made on Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:34:00 close-up of a moth on a leaf
00:00:38:00 large mushrooms in a grassy paddock
00:00:46:00 a woman slicing the mushrooms from the ground and collecting in a bucket
00:01:07:00 a largish spider runs up a canvas tent wall and the underside of a mushroom
00:01:22:00 peeling a large mushroom
00:01:52:00 a Coolabah brand wine cask and a poodle dog, mushrooms cooked on a camp stove
00:02:10:00 climbing over a stile in a fence
00:02:53:00 hikers climbing and helping each other over a rocky part of the trail
00:03:07:00 close-up of a spider in its web
00:04:07:00 descending a steep rock face
00:05:49:00 a iridescent blue and green beetle, tree lichen and a brown spider in its web
00:06:09:00 perfect light brown mushroom soon followed by another species of mushroom
00:06:54:00 several spiders on their webs
00:07:42:00 a variety of leather mushrooms
00:08:30:00 likely Ambicodamus crinitus spider
00:09:13:00 sign ‘Werribee Gorge’
00:09:30:00 hikers group sitting on the edge of a rocky cliff looking at the view, including a woman with binoculars
00:11:18:00 koala in close-up and and then climbing a tree
00:11:40:00 soaring Australian wedge-tailed eagle
00:12:07:00 group of (likely) bombadier beetles in green leaves
00:12:52:00 crossing the creek rock by rock
00:13:05:00 a small brown frog (likely litoria paraewingi)
00:13:12:00 hikers take a break - cameras, snacks and beer
00:15:02:00 overlooking tents at the camping site
00:15:17:00 wading the creek and a hiker rests with his dog on a hillside
00:15:55:00 leaf impressions on the rocks
00:16:36:00 1970s style cars - station wagons and camping van
00:16:55:00 two men using a manual post hole digger followed by scenes of fence making
00:17:29:00 planting new trees

results.title: Ceremony
results.creator_credit: David Greig and Experimental Film and Television Fund
results.brief_description: Nearly completing his painting, the artist takes a walk outside, where his creativity manifests itself in the life around him. This experimental work captures the ritualistic spirituality of art and the art in the everyday. Paintings in the film are by Paul Mason.
results.creator_credit_for_label: David Greig and Experimental Film and Television Fund

results.title: Return
results.brief_description: Static images of an old country house are combined with voices of the past to evocative effect. Haunting and nostalgic, ‘Return’ conveys the life that exists in old, abandoned places.

results.title: Witness
results.creator_credit: David Greig and Experimental Film and Television Fund
results.brief_description: Through intermingling static images of a playground, the beach and the town, David Greig paints a picture of Apollo Bay, on the west coast of Victoria, that is evocative and nostalgic.
results.creator_credit_for_label: David Greig and Experimental Film and Television Fund
